document.topic_text: Traffic switches to new SR 520 floating bridge Monday John Langeler reports. CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST SEATTLE, Wash. -- When traffic is reopened across Lake Washington on the new SR 520 bridge Monday morning, it will mark the end of a four-year process to modernize and enhance the toll crossing. While it represents the completion of $4.56 million of work, it does not mean construction on the highway is finished. Funding to reconstruct the west side of the crossing through Montlake to I-5 was approved by the legislature. At just over $2 billion, unfinished work includes HOV lanes, bike and pedestrian crossings and other enhancements including a pair of "lids", which are parks laid over the highway. "The changes are positive," commented Judy Ogliore, who lives above the highway in Montlake, "I think that when it's finished it will be really beautiful." "But we're ready for it to be done," she concluded. The West Approach Bridge connecting the new floating bridge to Seattle is expected to finish in 2017. Other aspects of the I-5 to Lake Washington project, including the park lids, will not be under construction until 2018, according to WSDOT plans. Copyright 2016 KING
